header.title: Dynamic Energetic Healing: Integrating Core Shamanic Practices with Energy Psychology Applications and Processwork Principles
header.category: Energy Healing, Shamanism, Psychotherapy, Esoteric Practices

central_thesis: Dynamic Energetic Healing® (DEH) proposes an integrative psychotherapeutic model that combines energy psychology, process-oriented psychology, and core shamanism. This synergistic approach aims to facilitate rapid, profound, and permanent healing of trauma, emotional problems, and spiritual issues by addressing energetic origins and imbalances at multiple levels of being—cognitive, somatic, subconscious, unconscious (collective unconscious/archetypal), energetic (chakras, meridians, biofield), and spiritual. A core methodology involves cultivating 'second attention' to perceive and work with subtle energies and spiritual forces, guided by Manual Muscle Testing (MMT) to ensure client-congruent and effective intervention selection.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 1: The Strands That Weave Dynamic Energetic Healing® Together
structure_content.summary: This section outlines the author's personal spiritual journey, from psychedelic experiences and Kundalini Yoga to Ericksonian Hypnosis, Processwork, and Core Shamanism, highlighting key influences and the philosophical foundations of DEH. It introduces core concepts like 'second attention,' 'dreamingbody,' 'compassionate spirits,' 'psychoenergetic reversal,' 'energetic origins,' 'soul loss,' and 'energetic boundaries,' framing them as interconnected elements crucial for understanding trauma and facilitating holistic healing within the DEH model.

The author shares his personal journey into spirituality, beginning with early psychedelic experiences and the opening of his heart chakra. He details his dedicated practice of Kundalini Yoga and meditation, which led to powerful energy surges and psychic phenomena, and an initiation called Shaktipat from Yogi Bhajan. This chapter sets the stage for his later integration of Eastern spiritual practices with Western psychology.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 2: Antecedents of Dynamic Energetic Healing®
structure_content.summary: This chapter surveys various psychotherapeutic models including Cognitive Therapy, Body-Centered Therapies, Transactional Analysis, Gestalt Therapy, Hypnotherapy, Self Psychology, and Psychodynamic Therapy, discussing their assumptions about healing. It introduces Process-Oriented Psychology and Energy Psychology, noting DEH's evolution from these, and highlights the concept of vital life force (prana, chi, ki, power, Holy Spirit) as a scientific, yet often unproven, energetic reality underlying these healing modalities. Applied kinesiology (MMT) and Thought Field Therapy (TFT) are presented as key developments in energy psychology.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 3: My Role within the Context of Dynamic Energetic Healing®
structure_content.summary: The author defines his role as a process-oriented therapist, emphasizing congruence, deep values, and multilevel awareness in the therapeutic context. He outlines five core beliefs of DEH, including the possibility of positive change and the awakening of the client's soul. The concept of 'second attention' is highlighted as crucial for perceiving energetic phenomena and guiding clients to trust their internal perceptions, facilitating self-empowerment beyond external validation.

Therapeutic presence is presented as the most vital element in energetic healing. The therapist's attitudes, expectations, and embodied energetic field directly influence healing outcomes. The author emphasizes 'in-the-moment awareness' and the therapist's expanded consciousness, which facilitates energy releases and deeper healing. This concept draws parallels with spiritual darshan, where the master's energy field positively affects the student, accelerating therapeutic change.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 5: Integrating the Second Attention into Dynamic Energetic Healing®: Acknowledging the Dreamingbody
structure_content.summary: This chapter defines 'second attention' as a cultivated awareness to notice subtle, unusual processes of the 'dreamingbody'—the continuous, fluid experience of reality beyond consensus reality. It explains how this awareness, drawn from Carlos Castaneda's teachings, allows the therapist to be highly sensitive to internal and external energetic phenomena, integrating the physical body as a central platform for healing. The dreamingbody facilitates access to deeper wisdom, empowering both client and therapist in the healing process.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 6: The Compassionate Spirits: Moving into the Dreamtime Experience
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces core shamanism as a foundational aspect of DEH, detailing the shamanic journey into nonordinary reality to interact with 'compassionate spirits.' It outlines the shamanic presuppositions: spirits are real, reality has three realms (upper, middle, lower world), and spirits help alleviate suffering. Key shamanic healing processes like divination, power animal retrieval, soul retrievals, extractions, and psychopomp work are described, emphasizing direct information from spirits and protection during these practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 7: Collaborating with the Compassionate Spirits: Embracing a New Paradigm
structure_content.summary: The author discusses the process of adjusting to and embracing the reality of compassionate spirits, which requires a paradigm shift beyond 'cognicentrism'—prejudice against nonordinary reality. He explains that accessing these spirits expands consciousness and extrasensory perception, empowering individuals. This collaboration is presented as a direct, empirical experience rather than faith, similar to the indwelling of the Holy Spirit, providing spiritual helpers for healing and protection.

This chapter explores the concept of 'intent' as an unmeasurable, indescribable force in the universe, as taught by Carlos Castaneda's Don Juan. It emphasizes aligning with this universal intent by 'cleaning one's connecting link' from egoic chatter and limiting beliefs. The DEH protocol uses Manual Muscle Testing to identify the client's highest priority intention, test for 'psychoenergetic reversal,' and ensure no 'inner parts' object, thereby activating conscious connection to this powerful, unlimited field of possibilities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 9: The Mysterious Phenomenon of Psychoenergetic Reversal
structure_content.summary: Psychoenergetic Reversal (PR) is defined as a self-sabotaging phenomenon where actions conflict with conscious desires, theorized as a reversal of electromagnetic or chi energy flow. It originates from long-term conditioning or traumatic incidents, embedding negative beliefs in the unconscious. MMT is crucial for detecting both 'generalized' and 'specific' PR. The chapter details generic energy psychology methods for correcting PR (e.g., rubbing sore points, affirmations) and DEH's process-oriented approach, which allows clients' inner wisdom to select the best intervention, such as NAEM, F/O holding, or tapping.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 10: Understanding Trauma within Dynamic Energetic Healing®
structure_content.summary: Trauma is distinguished from stress as a profound, often permanent experience that disrupts normal functioning, leading to PTSD. DEH recognizes that trauma causes energetic imbalances in meridians and chakras, affects the human biofield, and can manifest as ancestral or past-life energetic origins. It critiques mainstream psychiatry's reliance on medication, emphasizing DEH's holistic approach to identify and resolve these energetic origins, transforming trauma patterns without retraumatization and restoring the individual's full potential.

Soul loss is described as a predictable consequence of trauma in the shamanic tradition, where part of an individual's vital essence abandons the physical body, akin to Western psychology's dissociation. Symptoms include physical depletion, existential emptiness, difficulty staying present ('depersonalization'), and chronic depression. Shamans, with spirit helpers, journey into nonordinary realms (upper, middle, lower worlds) to locate and retrieve lost soul parts. DEH integrates this by identifying split-off parts within the energy field and using specific protocols to ensure 100% physical embodiment and restoration of energetic boundaries.

The author emphasizes the importance of consistent energetic practice, drawing from Kundalini Yoga and Qigong, to develop sensitivity to universal life-force energy (chi, prana) and expand consciousness. These practices, such as Kirtan Kriya meditation (using Sat Nam mantra) and Soaring Crane Qigong, stimulate chakras, balance endocrine systems, and open psychic abilities. The chapter highlights that systematic work with life-force energy, through focused visualization and breathing, is a precursor to an energetic-based psychotherapeutic orientation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 13: Energetic Origins from a Hypnotic Perspective
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the hypnotic aspects of the therapeutic relationship in DEH, emphasizing the creation of rapport to deepen internal orientation and openness to healing. The therapist's descriptive reporting of internal energetic experiences ('second attention') serves as modeling. Language itself is viewed as hypnotic, inducing 'transderivational search' (NLP) and altered states conducive to change. MMT is described as a hypnotic interaction, eliciting kinesthetic and proprioceptive channels, and enhancing suggestibility to facilitate profound energetic healing.

Energetic boundaries are crucial for maintaining personal power and harmony in relationships and various contexts, expanding beyond the codependency model. DEH uses MMT to identify compromised boundaries (e.g., with family, emotions, supernatural phenomena) and employs energetic strategies like Frontal Occipital (F/O) holding to restore them. The goal is to achieve an 'optimal, appropriate relationship' with disturbances, preventing disempowerment and enhancing the flow of vital energy. Case examples illustrate creativity in addressing boundary issues and the rapid shifts achieved at the quantum/energetic level.

DEH acknowledges supernatural phenomena ('dark energy' intrusions) as legitimate influences on mental and physical health, bridging the gap between traditional shamanism and energy psychology. These intrusions, often seen as negative energy forms (curses, malevolent entities), can block healing. The model recognizes their power and influence, advocating for effective strategies (MMT, F/O holding, spiritual allies) to release them, thereby protecting clients without religious overtones. This approach emphasizes the importance of personal spiritual grounding for practitioners.

This chapter elaborates on intrusions as external negative energies that can cause illness and psychological distress, often manifesting as depression or anxiety. The author provides personal experiences of detecting and clearing intrusions (e.g., in a hotel, dentist's office) using techniques like the Tibetan bell. It emphasizes that physical locations can retain and emit dark energy, making individuals vulnerable, especially when energetically weakened. Cultivating 'second attention' and regular energetic practice are crucial for developing sensitivity to and protecting oneself from these phenomena.

Sacred space, whether a physical location or an energetic field, is presented as vital for healing. DEH incorporates practices like daily affirmations by the therapist, inviting clients' spiritual resources, and using tools like sage and Tibetan bells to cleanse the therapeutic environment. This sacralization process brings in spiritual power, deep compassion, and allows profound healing to emerge, ensuring safety and support for both client and therapist. Following 'second attention' is key to maintaining this sacred space.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 2: The Dynamic Energetic Healing® Interventions
structure_content.summary: This part details the specific therapeutic interventions used in the DEH model, which stem from over twenty-four years of clinical experience and thirty years of spiritual practice. These interventions directly affect the client’s essential energy system (meridians, chakras, biofield) and are selected via Manual Muscle Testing (MMT). The author highlights the 'Resonance Factor,' where a practitioner's unique vibrational signature and passion enhance the effectiveness of chosen interventions. The interventions, including TAT, EFT, Tapping the Temporal Curve, NAEM, Chakra Tapping, F/O Holding, Vibrational Healing, Focused Prayer, and Core Shamanic Methods, are effective individually but synergistically powerful within the DEH methodology.

TAT, developed by Elizabeth Tapas Fleming, is a four-point acupressure protocol. The 'TAT Pose' involves specific finger placements on the bridge of the nose, forehead (stimulating the sixth chakra and bladder meridian), and occipital area (stimulating the Governing Vessel). This pose, combined with attuning to the problem, its opposite, energetic origins, and storage spaces, is designed to dissolve negative emotional charge and heal traumatic memories stored at cellular levels, including karmic memory, leading to a shift in a few minutes.

EFT, a streamlined derivative of Roger Callahan's Thought Field Therapy (TFT), involves tapping specific acupoints on meridians to eliminate emotional problems. Brockman's modified EFT includes tapping all twelve major meridians and two midline points (Central and Governing Vessels). The technique aims to collapse 'thought fields' of specific information perpetuating disturbances, thereby reorganizing the client's energy system to restore homeostasis. The protocol involves rating disturbance intensity (SUDS), tapping while attuned, and 'directive tapping' for abreactions, providing a rapid crisis-intervention tool.

Tapping the temporal curve bilaterally is an energy psychology intervention derived from ancient Chinese origins, discovered by George Goodheart Jr. to stimulate the brain for learning and create a sensory buffer. It sedates the triple warmer meridian, which perpetuates habits, allowing clients to challenge habit patterns and internal emotional conflicts more easily. The intervention involves repeating a conflict statement while tapping, often enhanced with associated eye movements, to correct neurological disorganization and stimulate neurovascular points on the head, yielding powerful results.

Chakras are presented as the body's essential energy centers, or 'spinning wheels,' that collect and distribute life-force energy (prana). Drawing from Kundalini Yoga, the chapter details the seven major chakras, their locations, associated endocrine glands, and emotional/psychological components (e.g., root chakra for survival/stability, sacral for creativity/sexuality, solar plexus for personal power/individuation, heart for love/compassion, throat for communication/integrity, third eye for intuition/psychic abilities, crown for spiritual connection). Tapping on specific chakras is a powerful DEH intervention to balance contracted energy and address imbalances.

NAEM, developed by Fred Gallo, is a powerful energy-based intervention for strong negative affects (fear, anger) or intrusive memories. It involves tapping four midline points (third-eye point, Governing Vessel point above upper lip, Central Vessel point below lower lip, heart chakra) while attuning to the disturbance. The effectiveness is attributed to various energy or quantum theories, suggesting these points balance the chi energy and collapse 'thought fields' perpetuating the problem. NAEM offers rapid alleviation of symptoms, though clients may experience cognitive dissonance due to the swift change.

F/O holding is a cornerstone of DEH, integrating energy psychology, core shamanism, and processwork. Developed by Three In One Concepts, it involves gently placing hands on the client's forehead and occipital bone, inducing an altered state. The therapist uses this contact to 'see' into the client's auric field, chakras, and karmic past lives, discerning stagnant energy, dark intrusions, and cognitive confusion. An invocation to the Great Spirit channels loving, healing, spiritual energies, facilitating spontaneous release of traumatic residue and transformations through the dreamtime experience. It also serves as a training tool for therapists to develop psychic abilities and maintain energetic boundaries.

DEH uses vibrational healing techniques, including Mantra, Toning, Tibetan bells/bowls/cymbals, and the healing drum, to create energetic balancing. Mantra, like the Kirtan Kriya (Sat Nam), uses specific vibrations to stimulate endocrine glands, balance chakras, and connect to universal energy. Tibetan instruments emit focused healing energies to dissolve dark/negative energies, enhance awareness, and induce deep relaxation. The healing drum, used for shamanic journeys, facilitates spirit communication and energetic extractions. These tools are 'power-filled' through personal spiritual connection, sacralizing the therapeutic process.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 3: The Dynamic Energetic Healing® Protocol
structure_content.summary: This section provides a step-by-step guide to the DEH protocol, designed for practitioners to systematically apply the integrative healing methods. It emphasizes preparing the groundwork (sacred space, MMT calibration, hydration), establishing a clear and congruent intention (testing for psychoenergetic reversal and inner parts' objections), working at the energetic origin (identifying type, using regression techniques, establishing energetic boundaries to prevent retraumatization), unpacking trauma components (affective residue, soul loss, intrusions, limiting beliefs), and completing/integrating the healing (karmic healing, power resources, future pacing).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 28: Preparing to Work on a Specific Intention
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the initial preparatory steps in the DEH protocol: building strong rapport with the client, educating them about DEH's psychospiritual framework, and creating a 'sacred space' to invite spiritual guidance and protection. Crucially, it details the calibration of Manual Muscle Testing (MMT) to ensure accuracy and reliability by testing client responses to 'yes' and 'no' statements, checking hydration, and ensuring the client’s energy field is circulating normally, addressing any 'polarity switches' or 'neurologic disorganization' for consistent results.

Before commencing deep healing, this chapter details how to establish a clear, congruent intention. It mandates testing for 'generalized' and 'specific psychoenergetic reversal' using MMT, as these self-sabotaging patterns can block treatment success. The process also involves prioritizing the client’s most highly valued therapeutic goal and, importantly, verifying through MMT that no 'inner parts' (dissociated aspects of the psyche) harbor objections to the stated intention. Addressing these objections, often linked to limiting beliefs or fears of protection, ensures whole-system alignment for healing.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 30: Working at the Energetic Origin
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on identifying and treating the 'energetic origin(s)'—pivotal, often traumatic events that are energetically linked to current problems. It defines four types: current lifetime, ancestral, past lifetime (karmic), and divine separation, and uses MMT to pinpoint them. Various regression techniques are described: 'affect bridge,' 'somatic bridge,' and 'NLP timeline regression,' all designed to access the origin without retraumatization by remaining 'suspended above the actual event.' The 'dreaming-up process' is introduced, explaining how unresolved trauma actively perpetuates symptoms in the present across different perceptual channels.

This chapter describes the 'unpacking' of the trauma package at its energetic origin, acknowledging trauma as a multifaceted phenomenon affecting body, mind, emotions, and spirit. It covers key components like affective residues (shock, fear, anger), soul loss, damaged energy fields, supernatural intrusions, and limiting beliefs. It introduces 'collective trauma' (absorbing others' traumatic stress) and the concept of 'death wish' as a severe consequence of violation trauma. The importance of establishing energetic boundaries with emotions and disidentifying from negative archetypes (Victim, Martyr, Judge) is emphasized, ensuring protection and reempowerment.

This concluding chapter focuses on solidifying healing outcomes. After clearing traumatic components at the energetic origin, the protocol addresses 'additional karmic healing,' which involves dialoguing with souls in the Bardo realm to resolve unfinished business and release resentment. It emphasizes creating a 'power resource' (an internal image or feeling state, an NLP technique) to anchor positive feelings. Finally, 'integrating the healing' involves directing clients to consciously bring the healed trauma forward through time into the present, and 'future pacing' helps them mentally rehearse successful future scenarios, ensuring no 'parts are left behind' and that any active 'dreaming-up process' is 'depotentiated' for lasting transformation.

This section provides detailed summaries of various client cases, illustrating the practical application of the Dynamic Energetic Healing® protocol. Each case highlights specific aspects of DEH, demonstrating how interventions like EFT, TAT, F/O holding, mantra, and shamanic techniques are combined to address complex issues such as panic attacks, post-surgical depression, childhood abuse trauma, allergies, cancer, bulimia, sexual abuse, acid reflux, loss and guilt from adoption, chronic fatigue, psychic attack, and depression related to energetic origins outside of worldly time. The case histories emphasize the process-oriented style, the role of the therapist's second attention, and the transformative outcomes achieved.

key_concepts.definition: An integrative psychotherapeutic model combining energy psychology, process-oriented psychology, and core shamanism to resolve trauma and foster spiritual growth by addressing energetic origins and imbalances at multiple levels of being.

A field that assumes change happens at the energetic level, using interventions like tapping on acupressure points and chakras to stimulate the flow of 'chi' or 'prana' and balance the energy body, leading to rapid emotional and cognitive shifts.

A methodology developed by Arnold Mindell, integrating Taoism, Jungian psychology, and quantum physics, that emphasizes following the 'Process'—the organic flow of unfolding events and 'dreamingbody' experiences—across various perceptual channels to achieve wholeness and personal freedom.

An ancient cross-cultural spiritual practice where the shaman enters 'nonordinary reality' through drumming or rattling to interact with 'compassionate spirits' for healing, divination, power animal retrieval, soul retrieval, extraction of intrusions, and psychopomp work.

A cultivated state of heightened awareness, borrowed from Carlos Castaneda, enabling the perception of subtle, unusual processes and energetic phenomena that normally appear in the background of consensus reality, crucial for engaging with the 'dreamingbody' and spiritual realms.

A concept from Processwork, referring to the continuous, fluid experience of reality beyond ordinary consciousness, encompassing bodily sensations, visions, dreams, feeling states, and intuition, which shamans use to travel between worlds and which is accessed through 'second attention'.

Real, conscious beings inhabiting nonordinary reality (upper, middle, and lower worlds) that shamans connect with through journeying to receive knowledge, wisdom, and healing power, dedicated to alleviating pain and suffering in the human world.

Pivotal events in a person's history (current lifetime, ancestral, past-life/karmic, divine separation) that create an energetic linkage responsible for current disturbances, holding significant emotional energy and trauma that influence present experiences and block intentions.

A phenomenon of self-sabotage, theorized as a conflict or reversal in the flow of one's electromagnetic or 'chi' energy, where actions are contrary to conscious desires. It can be generalized or specific to an issue, originating from conditioning or trauma, and is detected via Manual Muscle Testing.

A diagnostic tool used in DEH to obtain feedback from the client's energy system. By testing muscle strength or weakness in response to statements or thoughts, it identifies psychoenergetic reversals, energetic origins, internal conflicts, and the most effective interventions, serving as a reliable guide for the therapeutic process.

Invisible energetic perimeters that define one's personal power and integrity in relation to others, emotions, or specific contexts. When compromised by trauma or external influences, they lead to vulnerability and disempowerment; restoring them to 100% is a key DEH intervention to maintain emotional homeostasis and protect one's energy field.

In shamanic tradition, a consequence of trauma where a part of an individual's vital essence or 'soul' splits off from the physical body to survive an overwhelming experience. It leads to symptoms like physical depletion, existential emptiness, and chronic depression, requiring 'soul retrieval' to restore wholeness and energetic integrity.

External negative energies or entities (e.g., curses, angry earthbound spirits, malevolent thought forms) that become lodged in a person's energy field, often due to trauma or energetic weakness, causing physical and emotional disturbances. DEH uses shamanic methods and energy psychology techniques to identify, extract, and release these intrusions, often with the help of spiritual allies.

A category of DEH interventions that utilize sound and vibration to create energetic balancing and positive shifts. Techniques include Mantra (chanting spiritual formulas like Sat Nam), Toning (natural vocalizations), and the use of Tibetan bells, singing bowls, cymbals, and healing drums, all of which manipulate subtle energy fields for healing and consciousness expansion.

The body's essential energy system: Chakras are 'spinning wheels' or energy centers (seven major ones) along the spine, connected to glands and aspects of being; Meridians are pathways (twelve major ones, plus Central and Governing Vessels) through which 'chi' circulates. DEH interventions like tapping and holding target these points to unblock stagnant energy and restore balance.

The therapist's state of being fully present, open, and attuned to the client, embodying a positive healing attitude and expanded consciousness. This 'energetic radiation' fosters rapport, psychological safety, and enables the client to access deeper internal resources and facilitate transformative change.

A cosmic, unmeasurable force in the universe, beyond individual will, that all things are connected to. In DEH, establishing a clear intention for healing involves aligning with this universal 'intent,' clearing self-sabotaging patterns (PR), and addressing objections from inner parts, enabling the manifestation of desired realities.

practical_system.description: The Dynamic Energetic Healing® (DEH) Protocol is a structured yet flexible methodology for psychospiritual healing. It utilizes Manual Muscle Testing (MMT) as a core diagnostic tool to access the client's 'body wisdom' and 'soul wisdom,' guiding the selection and sequencing of interventions. The system emphasizes cultivating the therapist's 'second attention' and fostering a 'therapeutic presence' within a sacred space to work with subtle energy fields and spiritual forces. The primary goal is to identify and resolve 'energetic origins' of problems (current, ancestral, past-life, divine separation), clear 'psychoenergetic reversals,' establish 'energetic boundaries,' address 'soul loss,' remove 'supernatural intrusions' (dark energy, curses, spirit possession/obsession), and integrate healing on multiple levels (cognitive, emotional, physical, spiritual) for lasting transformation.
tools: Mantra/Chanting (e.g., Kirtan Kriya with Sat Nam)
Visualization (e.g., healing light, tunnel of light)
Spiritual Allies / Compassionate Spirits (e.g., power animals, divine figures like Jesus, Krishna, Gaia, Native American elders)
NLP Techniques (e.g., timeline regression, resource anchoring, transderivational search)
rituals: Creating a Sacred Space: An invocation to the Great Spirit and spiritual resources, often involving smudging with sage and/or chiming a Tibetan bell to cleanse and protect the therapeutic environment.
Manual Muscle Testing (MMT) Calibration: A preliminary process to ensure accuracy and reliability of MMT responses, checking for client hydration and normal energy field circulation.

Psychoenergetic Reversal (PR) Correction: Using MMT to identify general and specific self-sabotaging beliefs, followed by interventions (e.g., rubbing sore spots, NAEM, F/O Holding, Tibetan bell) to depolarize the energy field.

Identifying and Treating Energetic Origins: Using MMT to determine the type and number of origins (current-life, ancestral, karmic/past-life, divine separation) blocking an intention. Regression techniques like 'affect bridge,' 'somatic bridge,' and 'NLP timeline regression' guide the client to the origin's energy field.

Unpacking Trauma Package: Addressing affective residues (fear, anger, guilt), soul loss (using embodiment protocol or shamanic soul retrieval), damaged energy fields, supernatural intrusions (using extraction methods), and limiting beliefs with various energetic interventions (EFT, TAT, F/O Holding, chakra tapping, vibrational healing).

Soul Retrieval (Shamanic Method): Shamanic journeying with drumming/rattling to nonordinary reality to locate and return lost soul parts, often involving dialogue with the part and symbolic infusion into the client's heart/crown chakras.

Spirit Releasement/Extraction: Identifying and assisting earthbound spirits or dark energy intrusions to move to appropriate spiritual realms (e.g., Bardo state), often with the help of spiritual allies and specific interventions like F/O Holding or Tibetan bell.

Karmic Healing: Dialoguing with souls in the Bardo realm (after a past-life regression) to resolve unfinished business, forgive, and release resentment, often supported by F/O Holding and specific visualizations.
Creating a Power Resource (NLP): Intentionally anchoring a positive internal image or feeling state to new experiences, used to reelicit feelings of accomplishment and confidence.

Integrating Healing and Future Pacing: Using hypnotic language to integrate healed trauma forward through time, ensuring no parts are left behind, and mentally rehearsing successful future scenarios to prepare the client for desired outcomes and to 'depotentiate' active 'dreaming-up' processes.

relevant_quotes.text: As a model for psychotherapeutic change, Dynamic Energetic Healing® is as innovative and distinctive as it is remarkably effective. This book has been written for healthcare professionals and those who are interested in finding reliable ways to make long-lasting, positive changes in their lives.

DYNAMIC ENERGETIC HEALING® guides people to a place of thorough and complete emotional, mental, and spiritual healing, and of greater clarity regarding their life purpose. Dynamic Energetic Healing® is as effective with couples, families, and communities as it is with individuals.

Dynamic Energetic Healing® is many things, but at its essence it is an integrative model for practicing psychotherapy in a psychotherapeutic context. I am delighted to share this new healing model; I hope it will make you feel more comfortable in uncovering and accessing your spiritual resources in order to help others. The truth is, there is great power in the universe. Whether you call it prana or chi, archetypes or compassionate spirits, this power is all an expression of love.

The second attention is cultivated to notice unusual processes—the dreaming process that normally appears to us in the background (to the extent that we tend to ignore it). When you are in your second attention, you notice things on the periphery of your awareness. These experiences can be either external or internal, and may be subjective or irrational.

When I speak of “spirits,” it is because that is the way shamans talk within the system. To practice shamanism, it is unnecessary and even distracting to be preoccupied with achieving scientific understanding of what “spirits” may really represent and why shamanism works.

In the universe there is an unmeasurable, indescribable force which sorcerers call intent, and that absolutely everything that exists in the entire cosmos is attached to intent by a connecting link. They were especially concerned with cleaning it of the numbing effects brought about by the ordinary concerns of their everyday lives.
Psychoenergetic reversal (PR) (a term that I believe more accurately defines the phenomenon) is a form of self-sabotage that can block you from accomplishing your most important dreams.

The primary operative assumption of energy psychology is that human beings are infused with and circulating a kind of energy often referred to as the vital life force. There have been various names for this vital life force throughout history and within many different spiritual traditions. This energy is called prana in the practice of yoga, chi in Chinese medicine, ki in the Korean martial-arts traditions, power in the shamanic tradition, and the Holy Spirit in the Christian tradition.

Soul loss is regarded as the gravest diagnosis in the shamanic nomenclature, being seen as a cause of illness and death. Yet it is not referred to at all in modern Western medical books. Nevertheless, it is becoming increasingly clear that what the shaman refers to as soul loss—that is, injury to the inviolate core that is the essence of the person’s being—does manifest in despair, immunological damage, cancer, and a host of other very serious disorders.

DYNAMIC ENERGETIC HEALING® is an integrative model that benefits from the synthesis of a variety of powerful healing modalities. Using this approach leads to rapid, consistent, positive therapeutic outcomes that are experientially verifiable in each session. For the most part, complete elimination of traumatic residue from old injury is a predictable outcome of the use of Dynamic Energetic Healing® techniques. I feel very excited to have this opportunity to share this new approach with you.

critical_analysis.relevance: Dynamic Energetic Healing® bridges ancient esoteric and spiritual practices (shamanism, Kundalini yoga, Chinese medicine) with contemporary Western psychological frameworks, offering a unique 'psychospiritual' healing paradigm. It is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism by legitimizing non-ordinary reality experiences, the existence of subtle energies (chi, prana, auric fields), and spiritual entities (compassionate spirits, dark intrusions) within a structured, practical, and verifiable healing methodology. The integration of concepts like 'second attention,' 'dreamingbody,' 'energetic origins' (including karmic/past-life and ancestral), and 'psychoenergetic reversal' provides a technical language and operative framework for understanding and resolving complex energetic and spiritual blockages. By emphasizing direct experience, intention, and collaboration with spiritual forces, DEH positions itself as an applied magical system for personal transformation, distinct from faith-based religious or purely intellectual therapeutic approaches.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book targets healthcare professionals (therapists, social workers, acupuncturists), energy healers, spiritual practitioners (shamans, yogis), and individuals committed to deep personal transformation and spiritual growth. It is particularly useful for those interested in bridging traditional psychological models with esoteric healing modalities, providing both theoretical grounding and practical techniques. The emphasis on supervised training and ethical application suggests a professional audience, while the clear descriptions and case histories make it accessible to dedicated lay practitioners seeking self-healing or ways to assist others.
